quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our chat, we get incredibly tactical about all of the ways that you can grow your product, including when and how to invest in virality, SEO, and paid growth.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical decision focus on timing and allocation across key growth channels (virality, SEO, paid).

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: What's changing across each of those channels and the most common failure modes for B2C startups.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points practitioners to look for shifting channel dynamics and recurring pitfalls as a way to de-risk growth strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: This is the most tactical and actionable conversation I have had yet on how to grow your product, particularly a subscription product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Signals that the episode’s core value is concrete, implementable guidance specifically for subscription growth.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Well, based on our data, about a third of people will consider switching to another company after just one bad experience during onboarding.
quotes.speaker: Ashley
quotes.context: A concrete retention risk data point that quantifies how costly onboarding friction can be.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So if your CSV importer doesn't work right, which is super common, considering customer files are chalk full of unexpected data and formatting they'll leave.
quotes.speaker: Ashley
quotes.context: Highlights a common failure mode (messy real-world data) and the direct consequence: churn.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I've consistently seen that improving onboarding is one of the highest leverage opportunities for both signup, conversion and increasing long term retention.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A prioritization heuristic: onboarding improvements can drive multiple core metrics at once.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Getting people to your aha moment more quickly and reliably is so incredibly important.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical product-growth mental model: optimize onboarding around reaching the “aha moment” faster and more consistently.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's because flawless data onboarding acts like a catalyst to get them and their customers where they need to go faster.
quotes.speaker: Ashley
quotes.context: A memorable framing that positions data onboarding as an accelerant for customer success and growth.

quotes.topic_title: Yuriy’s advising work and capacity
quotes.text: I've probably worked with maybe 15 companies in the last two and a little bit of years. Obviously, not all at once. It's usually four to five at any given point in time.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Gives a concrete benchmark for how many advisory engagements are feasible over time and concurrently.

quotes.topic_title: Yuriy’s advising work and capacity
quotes.text: I hard count my week at about three to three and a half days a week worth of work, which is a personal choice. And so that is a hard constraint that I'm working with.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Models a capacity-planning approach: set a non-negotiable time constraint first, then design workload around it.

quotes.topic_title: Yuriy’s advising work and capacity
quotes.text: And within that constraint, I also feel like for me to do my best work and the work that I also enjoy the most and find the most fulfilling four to five companies is probably the max.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on capping concurrent commitments to maintain quality and personal fulfillment.

quotes.topic_title: Yuriy’s advising work and capacity
quotes.text: If I try to go beyond that, the overhead that it creates in terms of the cost of context switching just becomes overwhelming. I feel like I'm not showing up as best as I can with each individual company.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Highlights context-switching as the limiting factor—useful for anyone balancing multiple projects or clients.

quotes.topic_title: Yuriy’s advising work and capacity
quotes.text: But I think for every four to five companies that I'm working with, think of it as a concentric circles, right? There are another, maybe 10 to a dozen companies that we're actively exploring if we want to work together in the future. And then there is another concentric circle so maybe 30 plus companies that I'm just friends with.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Provides a simple “concentric circles” pipeline model for managing relationships and future work without overcommitting.

quotes.topic_title: Growth archetypes for subscription businesses
quotes.text: So if I think about subscription companies, I think there are probably a couple of buckets that I see them falling into.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Introduces a practical mental model (growth “buckets”) for diagnosing which growth motion a subscription business should prioritize.

quotes.topic_title: Growth archetypes for subscription businesses
quotes.text: Most consumer subscription companies that are $5 to $7 a month. Their LTVs typically cap out at 50 to 60 bucks.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Provides a concrete benchmark for consumer subscription LTV that helps teams sanity-check whether paid acquisition can work.

quotes.topic_title: Growth archetypes for subscription businesses
quotes.text: If I'm seeing things like that and I'm seeing that you're converting seven, like five plus percent of your free users to a paid subscriber, then there is a big opportunity to play paid and lean into paid growth loops and paid acquisition loops.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Gives actionable decision criteria (healthy LTV + 5%+ free-to-paid conversion) for when to invest in paid growth.

quotes.topic_title: Growth archetypes for subscription businesses
quotes.text: Another archetype I see are companies that can lead into SEO very heavily, especially if there is a long tail programmatic angle.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Highlights a specific growth archetype—programmatic long-tail SEO—as a repeatable engine for certain subscription products.

quotes.topic_title: Growth archetypes for subscription businesses
quotes.text: Take Canva for instance, their biggest initial growth loop and I think this is public knowledge was their long tail SEO strategy where any kind of design project that you could think of would search for designing.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Anchors the SEO archetype with a concrete example of Canva’s early growth loop built on long-tail search demand.

quotes.topic_title: When virality and referrals actually work
quotes.text: Honestly, the first thing you look for is that, is there inherent product network effects? It's something that it's either there, or isn't from inception from my experience. I think it's very difficult to manufacture.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A practical litmus test for whether virality is worth investing in: check for built-in network effects rather than trying to create them later.

quotes.topic_title: When virality and referrals actually work
quotes.text: You'd only study when... It's very hard to manufacture product network effects if they aren't there from the get go.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that “manufactured virality” is usually an uphill battle if network effects weren’t designed in from day one.

quotes.topic_title: When virality and referrals actually work
quotes.text: So if you have inherent product network effects, that's when I think layering on referral loops and viral loops. You think about what Dropbox has done around file sharing. That's an iconic example.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Actionable sequencing: first ensure network effects exist, then amplify growth by adding referral/viral loops (with Dropbox as the model).

quotes.topic_title: When virality and referrals actually work
quotes.text: Then it's really powerful. I think that there is another case where referral and viral loops could work even when there are inherent network effects. If you have a really beloved product, beloved brand.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A second pathway to referrals: strong brand love can drive sharing even without classic network effects.

quotes.topic_title: When virality and referrals actually work
quotes.text: There's a company out of Australia that I have opportunity to invest it called Laika. They do fresh dog food subscriptions and incredibly beloved brand, a premium product. And so they're able to lean into a give one, get one referrals, even though there isn't inherent product network effects, they're still able to generate meaningful results off of the, and incentivize referring program.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Concrete example of referrals working without network effects via a “give one, get one” program powered by a beloved premium brand.

quotes.topic_title: SEO readiness: editorial, programmatic, data angles
quotes.text: I mean, there are a couple of pillars, because obviously we all know that SEO has a different return horizon than say paid acquisition. It's longer out. It's maybe six months is the earliest you can see results. Even then it's going to be a small trickle that compounds over time, if you're successful or you may spend three to six months leaning into an SEO strategy and then realize that it's not going to back out typically at least in historically a company probably isn't like Series B before it starts feeling like it passed a luxury of making these kind of medium to long term investments.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Sets realistic expectations for SEO timelines and highlights the risk of investing months before knowing if it will pay off.

quotes.topic_title: SEO readiness: editorial, programmatic, data angles
quotes.text: So I think with SEO, it's like the first pillar I would say is, do you have a unique angle when you take a look at the SEO landscape today, you look at editorial, the landscape, which is to how to searches and who are the players there and what kind of information is being offered? Do you have something unique to contribute to that conversation?
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Provides a concrete readiness test: only invest if you can differentiate in the editorial/how-to SERP landscape.

quotes.topic_title: SEO readiness: editorial, programmatic, data angles
quotes.text: Another thing if I have to do an audit checklist, another thing is, do you have a unique programmatic angle, right? For instance, Canva did dealt with templates.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Introduces programmatic SEO as a second pillar and anchors it with a specific example (Canva templates).

quotes.topic_title: SEO readiness: editorial, programmatic, data angles
quotes.text: or the other one is, do you have a unique data angle? So for instance, a company I work with called Monarch Money, which is in the personal finance management space. Think of it as a new and improved version of MIT. There is a lot of users are connecting accounts and you have a sense percenting patterns and things like that. Clearly there is a unique data, and so it's a question of, can you turn it into some kind of valuable organic search experience?
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Highlights proprietary data as a third SEO moat and frames the key question: can the data become a search experience.

quotes.topic_title: SEO readiness: editorial, programmatic, data angles
quotes.text: If you can check two of those three boxes as a back of the envelope framework, you may be in good shape. And then it's a question of like, "How can you lower the cost of experimentation SEO as much as possible?" I think as a rule of thumb, if you can time box it to three months, what can I do at the end of three months? Is this likely to work or not?
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Gives a practical decision rule (2 of 3 pillars) and an execution tactic (3-month time-boxed experiment) to reduce SEO risk.

quotes.topic_title: SEO execution: audits, specialists, and Graphite
quotes.text: I think SEO is pretty specialized skill set.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Frames SEO as a distinct discipline where generalist effort often underperforms specialist expertise.

quotes.topic_title: SEO execution: audits, specialists, and Graphite
quotes.text: there is a lot of more nuance, SEO developments and angles, where I think is where the opportunity really lies to differentiate yourself. And that requires keeping up with the latest algorithm changes. It's very hard to do that unless you are specializing in the art where the black magic of SEO, and so that's why I think getting an outside resource at least for an audit is really helpful.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Explains why differentiation in SEO comes from staying current on nuanced changes, making external audits a high-leverage move.

quotes.topic_title: SEO execution: audits, specialists, and Graphite
quotes.text: you can get these relatively inexpensive audits done from companies that you can then choose. Do I hire them to help with my SEO or not?
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Suggests using an audit as a low-risk way to evaluate SEO upside and potential partners before committing.

quotes.topic_title: SEO execution: audits, specialists, and Graphite
quotes.text: I think that audit is usually a very good use of time because they have templates. So what they can turn around for five to 10K would take you many, many human hours to try to pull together yourself.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Provides a concrete cost/time tradeoff to justify buying an SEO audit instead of building one internally.

quotes.topic_title: SEO execution: audits, specialists, and Graphite
quotes.text: I think one of the most innovative, disciplined first principles SEO thinkers and I have met is Ethan Smith from Graphite.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Names a specific high-end resource and highlights “first principles” thinking as a differentiator in SEO expertise.

quotes.topic_title: Paid growth shifts: payback windows and attribution
quotes.text: So before for a consumer subscription company, 12 month payback was decent. Now it's like, you better pay back your paid media in six months or less. That's the sentiment.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark shift practitioners can use to recalibrate CAC/LTV targets and paid spend thresholds in today’s market.

quotes.topic_title: Paid growth shifts: payback windows and attribution
quotes.text: Now it's like, especially with venture back companies, you have to have two plus years of runway, managers burn a lot more diligently now. And so whatever you can't attribute to sales sue like, "That shits got to go."
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A blunt operating rule: in tighter markets, unattributed spend becomes a primary cut target, forcing better measurement discipline.

quotes.topic_title: Paid growth shifts: payback windows and attribution
quotes.text: However, that opens up an opportunity for smart kind of attribution investments.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Counterintuitive takeaway: worsening tracking conditions can create advantage for teams that invest in attribution and incrementality.

quotes.topic_title: Paid growth shifts: payback windows and attribution
quotes.text: The companies that had strong cash positions, have strong unit economics, strong paid back periods already like Grammarly, Canva to name two that I know personally.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Specific examples of the profile of companies positioned to win in a paid downturn—useful for benchmarking readiness.

quotes.topic_title: Paid growth shifts: payback windows and attribution
quotes.text: And so those that have been disciplined, have the instrumentation to track things better than average. They're going to benefit from decreased competition on app platforms, decreasing CPMs, et cetera.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A practical playbook: disciplined unit economics + superior measurement can turn market pullbacks into cheaper inventory and growth leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Attribution tools: MMM and incrementality testing
quotes.text: Media Mix Modeling is now making a comeback because there are so many offline channels that are part of folks channel portfolio today and that plus a lot of the online channels are becoming less trackable like Meta for instance, with the iOS 14 shift.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Explains why MMM is resurging: offline channel mix plus declining trackability in digital (e.g., iOS 14).

quotes.topic_title: Attribution tools: MMM and incrementality testing
quotes.text: I think it's useful if you're spending a considerable amount, what's considerable, I'd say worth of a hundred thousand a month update media. And if you have some level of channel complexity, so you're not just like a Google Go or a Facebook, but maybe you're on three plus the channels.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Gives a practical threshold (spend + channel complexity) for when MMM becomes worth considering.

quotes.topic_title: Attribution tools: MMM and incrementality testing
quotes.text: Click based attribution or the digital attribution were all fawning over cookie based and click based, a real parameter based attribution. It never demonstrated a causal relationship between our media spend and business results. It was only good for correlative insights.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Challenges the conventional reliance on click/cookie attribution by distinguishing correlation from causation.

quotes.topic_title: Attribution tools: MMM and incrementality testing
quotes.text: And the only way to determine causality is through real controlled experiments, randomized control experiments through incrementality testing, which is typically really hard to do cleanly and also companies have always been often wary about doing it because you have to turn off a channel potentially in a key demo and you're like, "Yeah."
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Provides the core measurement methodology (RCT incrementality tests) and the key operational barrier (having to turn off a channel).

quotes.topic_title: Attribution tools: MMM and incrementality testing
quotes.text: But the only way to really know how effective your paid media is through ongoing incrementality testing.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A crisp, memorable directive that emphasizes continuous experimentation as the standard for paid media effectiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Focus vs spreading thin across channels
quotes.text: I would say focus paired with rapid iterations, right?
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A simple operating principle for balancing prioritization with learning speed in early growth.

quotes.topic_title: Focus vs spreading thin across channels
quotes.text: You can not burn. That there is a finite number of tries that you have at finding what works, right?
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Frames growth experimentation as a constrained resource, pushing teams to be deliberate about what they test.

quotes.topic_title: Focus vs spreading thin across channels
quotes.text: And just in case, it's not obvious if you focus on one thing and it ends up being the wrong thing, you've wasted really valuable time and now you have so much less time left to find something that does work.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Warns against over-focusing too early because the opportunity cost is runway and learning cycles.

quotes.topic_title: Focus vs spreading thin across channels
quotes.text: If you get them to try five different things, they may not try them anyone individually fully enough, because I like to say the only thing that's worse than a channel or a tactic that you tried not working. The only thing that's worse now is when you didn't give it the appropriate shot and you pretty much surely or erroneously concluded that it doesn't work.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Highlights the hidden failure mode of shallow tests: false negatives that kill viable channels prematurely.

quotes.topic_title: Focus vs spreading thin across channels
quotes.text: And it's remarkable how often you find that to be the case when I talk to companies, "Oh, YouTube, we tried it doesn't work." I'm like, "Okay, can I see what you've tried?" And then you look at it and you're like, "Oh, this thing was not designed to even have a shot at working from the get go."
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A concrete example of how teams misdiagnose channel failure due to poor execution rather than channel mismatch.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Wherever you work, running experiments is increasingly essential, but there are no commercial tools that integrate with a modern grow team stack.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical gap teams face: experimentation is mandatory, but tooling often doesn’t fit modern stacks, creating friction.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This leads to waste of time building internal tools or trying to run your experiments through a clunky marketing tool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable warning about the hidden cost of poor experimentation tooling—either DIY overhead or misusing ill-suited tools.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I love about our experimentation platform was being able to easily slice results by device, by country, and by user stage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of an experimentation methodology: segmenting results to uncover where effects differ across cohorts.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic click-through metrics and instead you turn north star metrics like activation, retention, subscriptions and payments.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Encourages a metrics framework shift from shallow CTR to business outcomes tied to the north star.

quotes.topic_title: Knowing when to stop: guardrails and judgment
quotes.text: I think with some tactics and some channels you can fairly objectively create some test guard rails where it's like, if it's YouTube, we know kind of minimum number of impressions that you got to get. Try two to three creative angles. Here's the click through rates range that you're looking for. If you get within these ranges on these KPIs, keep going. If you don't, abandon.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A concrete, benchmark-driven framework for deciding when to continue vs. stop a channel test (impressions, creative angles, CTR ranges).

quotes.topic_title: Knowing when to stop: guardrails and judgment
quotes.text: I think that's important to also know that abandonment doesn't mean we will never revisit it again, right? It just means that because every time you're evaluating, the concept of sunk cost.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Reframes “abandoning” an initiative as a sunk-cost-aware pause rather than a permanent decision.

quotes.topic_title: Knowing when to stop: guardrails and judgment
quotes.text: So you have these periodic, I think periods of reevaluation where it's like, "Okay, did we try enough? Is this more art than science frankly." It's like, "What's the incremental lift for us as a team to try to experiment with the next phase of this channel or this tactic? What is the opportunity cost of that? What are the other high profile things that we could be trying?"
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A decision checklist for when to keep investing: assess “did we try enough,” incremental lift, and opportunity cost during periodic reevaluations.

quotes.topic_title: Knowing when to stop: guardrails and judgment
quotes.text: I would break things down maybe into two types. There are some channels or tactics where you can objectively figure out som guard rails for when it's showing promise or not, because you can pull benchmarks on good click through rates and things like that. Then there are other tactics where you just have to exercise more judgment outside of benchmarks.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A simple two-bucket model: benchmarkable channels vs. judgment-based bets that require different stop/continue criteria.

quotes.topic_title: The 80/20 reality and diversification timing
quotes.text: Definitely the 80/20 applies. There is a kind of strategy that's working overwhelmingly well, and there is a scramble internally to minimize reliance on that one thing.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A reality check that even admired companies often depend on one dominant growth engine—and must actively manage concentration risk.

quotes.topic_title: The 80/20 reality and diversification timing
quotes.text: In the case of Grammarly, it was performance marketing kind of over reliance on performance marketing during part of the company's life cycle.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A concrete example of a major company being heavily dependent on a single channel, illustrating how concentration happens in practice.

quotes.topic_title: The 80/20 reality and diversification timing
quotes.text: With Canva, it was the SEO angle. So for them, that was working really well, which is more defensible than paid. That's sort of long tail programmatic SEO angle, but look, you're always susceptible to Google algorithm updates and so how do you derisk yourself from that?
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A nuanced channel-risk model: SEO can be more defensible than paid, yet still fragile due to platform dependency (Google updates).

quotes.topic_title: The 80/20 reality and diversification timing
quotes.text: No, no. Too early. I'm glad that you're such a forward thinker. Put all of your energy. Sure, this one tactic is accounting for say 80 plus percent of your new user acquisition, but your user acquisition is still small. So don't get distracted with diversification. We'll get there.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance for early-stage teams: resist premature diversification and double down until the core engine is truly scaled.

quotes.topic_title: The 80/20 reality and diversification timing
quotes.text: Contrast that with some later stage companies for who are... At scale, I know 50 plus million ARR, 90 plus percent reliant on a single acquisition channel, which just mire with risk and diversification is a blind spot for them.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A specific scale benchmark showing when channel concentration becomes a serious business risk and diversification becomes urgent.

quotes.topic_title: Why “later-stage” tactics are moving earlier
quotes.text: We were living in a world where funding was abundant and plentiful, startups were conditions to think that they could raise twice a year. Valuations were quite toppling within a year. You raise in January and then you raise in November and your valuation five X.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A concrete example of how easy capital and rapid valuation jumps pushed startups toward short-term growth behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Why “later-stage” tactics are moving earlier
quotes.text: We got to grow as quickly as possible. What can we activate to give us immediate return?" And the answer is almost always paid.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for why early-stage teams default to paid channels when optimizing for near-term fundraising milestones.

quotes.topic_title: Why “later-stage” tactics are moving earlier
quotes.text: Because payoff is going to come maybe in 12 months in terms of meaningful payoff. We care about getting to the next round and maximizing our valuation between now and then. SEO is for the grown up companies.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Captures the time-horizon mismatch that causes companies to delay compounding channels like SEO until later stages.

quotes.topic_title: Why “later-stage” tactics are moving earlier
quotes.text: You have to extend your runway, minimize burn, high burning if you have to.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A direct operational directive reflecting the shift from growth-at-all-costs to survival and sustainability.

quotes.topic_title: Why “later-stage” tactics are moving earlier
quotes.text: Can't afford to be acquiring users at like LTV cap one to one." That's now a no-no.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A clear unit-economics constraint that changes which growth levers are viable in tighter funding environments.

quotes.topic_title: Paid as learning vs paid as scalable engine
quotes.text: So there are two pieces to do paid. I mean I'm oversimplifying, but I think people will hopefully appreciate the over the oversimplification. Number one, because it actually drives returns at efficient unit economic, whatever that may mean for your company, your business, your industry. The other way to do it is because it's a very quick way to get learnings on messaging and positioning on designs on features.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Defines a clear two-mode framework for paid acquisition: scalable growth engine vs rapid learning/experimentation tool.

quotes.topic_title: Paid as learning vs paid as scalable engine
quotes.text: I think the problem that I find is when a company can't have which camper in or where they try to say that they're in both, but really it's like, "Okay, you're funneling a hundred K a month." It's super inefficient and they're not even running experiments to actually get the learnings.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Warns against the common failure mode of spending heavily on paid without committing to either profitability or disciplined learning.

quotes.topic_title: Paid as learning vs paid as scalable engine
quotes.text: If I see that they're not there because the funnel doesn't convert well, the users don't retain the LTDs are too low. Then I say, "Hey, it's not time for paid. Maybe car on a little bit of budget if you want to quickly test positioning and things like that. But it's just too soon."
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Gives actionable gating criteria for when paid is premature, and how to still use small budgets for learning.

quotes.topic_title: Paid as learning vs paid as scalable engine
quotes.text: Yeah. I can confidently say a healthy website visit to a free user, a free account creation conversion rate. It's probably in that 20 to 35% range.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Provides a concrete benchmark for prosumer funnels (site visit → free signup) to assess funnel health before scaling paid.

quotes.topic_title: Paid as learning vs paid as scalable engine
quotes.text: What about a conversion if you're premium from a free user to a premium account or paying account? I think anything under 5% is not going to work long term, regardless of how big your top of funnel is. You may get the soft point, but for you to remain an independent company continuously growing pre IPO, I don't think it's going to happen. It's got to be north of 5%, ideally like more than 7%.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Sets a hard threshold for free→paid conversion that challenges “just grow top-of-funnel” thinking and informs go/no-go decisions on paid scaling.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding as a major growth lever
quotes.text: Almost always.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A strong heuristic that onboarding investment is typically a high-ROI lever, especially in complex products.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding as a major growth lever
quotes.text: So the products tend to be more complex. Airtable, whimsical, Canva, InVideo. They're very robust products. And so it's very easy to get lost in their editors.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Explains why onboarding matters most in robust prosumer tools: complexity creates disorientation and drop-off risk.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding as a major growth lever
quotes.text: So when they're trying to democratize access, but they're also trying to make the products robust enough to be comparable to a professional great quality. And it's a very difficult place to play it, right? It's like, how do you make it simple enough where a nonprofessional can use it, but robust enough where they go and say, "Oh yeah, this is as good as if I would've hired a professional fill in the blank."
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A memorable framing of the core prosumer tension—simplicity vs professional-grade power—that onboarding must resolve.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding as a major growth lever
quotes.text: That's where onboarding is really, really important because there's such a huge difference between landing someone on that initial editor page, be it Airtable, Canva having that left to their own devices versus getting as much information or as much relevant information front and then customizing that landing experience for them.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: collect relevant info upfront and tailor the first experience rather than dropping users into a generic editor.

quotes.topic_title: Onboarding as a major growth lever
quotes.text: So that if they're there to do X and we know XYZ about them, we're able to guide them and not expose them to the robustness of the product all at once. So the short answer is almost all the time onboarding is a big opportunity.
quotes.speaker: Yuriy Timen
quotes.context: A practical onboarding principle: guide users based on intent and progressively reveal complexity to accelerate time-to-value.
